replies.body:
So in regards to your concern of false reports, there should (ideally) be nothing to worry about. False reports should be pretty much debunked and thrown away by the system, whether it's done via automated or manual review. That said, the system isn't perfect so it can happen that the automated system (even a manual review) might trigger an unwarranted punishment, in which case your best bet would be to appeal by submitting a ticket to [Support](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us).

I'm a bit unclear on the details of what's up-to-date information, but false reports will either be treated as "irrelevant" and thrown away (no "backlash" on the person doing the reporting) *or* it's still under the old system where each player (rather, account) has a "general report weight" which is positively or negatively influenced by accurate and false reports, respectively.

As ThatsBS has already mentioned, there is a "no name-and-shame" policy on the boards, so keep that in mind for the future. It's best just to abide by it, not just to avoid "witch-hunting" on players but also to avoid unnecessary boards-bans on your account (beside, there are other places you can give out their names where Riot can't do anything, if you really want).

The Tribunal was a great concept, and a great way to get the community involved with moderation and establishing a "culture" of acceptable and unacceptable behaviours. That said, there doesn't appear to be any updates on what has actually happened to the Tribunal, it appears the concept is something Riot has probably given up on at this point. Ideally, they'd still have it in the works and just not satisfied that it meets a reasonable standard, but I wouldn't expect that to be the case.

Really, the best way to be involved with moderation and establishing that "culture" is to use the report system to notify Riot anytime you see behaviours you don't agree with. It's really the best we have at the moment, and not much can be done if Riot aren't acting on that feedback as they should. Unfortunate, but true.

As for the "automated vs manual" reviews, that's really something that comes down to Riot's internal systems. Most cases would be reviewed by the automated systems, which are designed to learn and adapt based on the behaviours that are reported. In some cases, a manual review would be required because of the limitations of the automated system, and sometimes manual reviews are done as a way to "monitor" the automated system, to try and keep it on the right track (you'll find people will have varying opinions of how effective that is). As far as I understand it, that's the way the system is designed to work.
